revision.text:
{{For|use in cryptography|Key signature (cryptography)}} [[File:A-major f-sharp-minor.svg|thumb|right|150px|Key signature [[A major]] / [[F-sharp minor|F{{music|#}} minor]] with three sharps placed after the clef.]] In [[musical notation]], a '''key signature''' is a set of [[Sharp (music)|sharp]] ({{Music|sharp}}), [[Flat (music)|flat]] ({{Music|b}}), and rarely, [[Natural (music)|natural]] ({{Music|natural}}) symbols placed together on the [[staff (music)|staff]]. Key signatures are generally written immediately after the [[clef]] at the beginning of a line of musical notation, although they can appear in other parts of a [[Sheet music|score]], notably after a [[Bar (music)|double barline]]. A key signature designates [[note (music)|note]]s that are to be played higher or lower than the corresponding [[natural sign|natural]] notes and applies through to the end of the piece or up to the next key signature. A sharp symbol on a line or space in the key signature raises the notes on that line or space one [[semitone]] above the natural, and a flat lowers such notes one semitone. Further, a symbol in the key signature affects all the notes of one letter: for instance, a sharp on the top line of the [[Clef#Treble clef|treble staff]] applies to Fs not only on that line, but also to Fs in the bottom space of the staff, and to any other Fs. This convention was not universal until the late [[Baroque music|Baroque]] and early [[Classical period (music)|Classical period]], however; music published in the 1720s and 1730s, for example, uses key signatures showing sharps or flats on both octaves for notes which fall within the staff.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} An [[Accidental (music)|accidental]] is an exception to the key signature, applying only in the measure in which it appears. Although a key signature may be written using any combination of sharp and flat symbols, the most common series of thirteen homogeneous key signatures—ranging from six flats to six sharps, with each successive flat or sharp placed on the [[circle of fifths|note a perfect fifth below or above]], respectively, the previous one—is assumed in much of this article. A piece scored using a single diatonic key signature and no accidentals contains notes of at most seven of the twelve [[pitch class]]es, which seven being determined by the particular key signature. Each [[Major scale|major]] and [[Minor scale|minor]] [[key (music)|key]] has an associated key signature that sharpens or flattens the notes which are used in its scale. However, it is not uncommon for a piece to be written with a key signature that does not match its key, for example, in some Baroque pieces,Schulenberg, David. ''Music of the Baroque''. New York: Oxford University Press, 2001. [https://books.google.com/books?id=P4x3aKvOQWAC&pg=PA72&vq=%22the+key+of+a+baroque+work%22&source=gbs_search_r&cad=1_1&sig=ACfU3U3x7lhOyyIiT-O_HsTZlZxw8FrkSA p. 72.]. "(…) to determine the key of a Baroque work one must always analyze its tonal structure rather than rely on the key signature." or in transcriptions of traditional modal folk tunes.Cooper, David. ''The Petrie Collection of the Ancient Music of Ireland''. Cork: Cork University Press, 2005. [https://books.google.com/books?id=PzrfncNnr4cC&pg=PA25-IA13&vq=%22In+a+few+cases+Petrie+has+given+what+is+clearly+a+modal+melody+a+key+signature+which+suggests+that+it+is+actally+in+a+minor+key%22&source=gbs_search_r&cad=1_1&sig=ACfU3U0BqVPTuQnnaH32iLpCvrYnyT143Q p. 22]. "In a few cases Petrie has given what is clearly a modal melody a key signature which suggests that it is actually in a minor key. For example, ''Banish Misfortune'' is presented in D minor, although it is clearly in the Dorian mode." Later on, this use of a key signature that is theoretically incorrect for a piece as a whole or a self-contained section of a piece became less common (in contrast to brief passages within a piece, which, as they modulate from key to key often temporarily disagree with the key signature); but it can be found at least as late as one of Beethoven's very late piano sonatas. For example, in his [[Piano Sonata No. 31 (Beethoven)|Sonata No. 31 in A{{music|flat}} major, Op. 110]], the first appearance of the Arioso section in the final movement is notated throughout in six flats; but it both begins and ends in A{{music|flat}} minor and has a significant modulation to C{{music|flat}} major, and both these keys theoretically require seven flats in their key signature. (The second appearance later in the movement of this same section, a semitone lower, in G minor, uses the correct key signature of two flats.) == Conventions == [[File:ks1.gif|thumb|right|200px|1. [[B major]] scale: no key signature; accidentals required throughout]] {{anchor|scale2}}[[File:ks2.gif|thumb|right|200px|2. [[B major]] scale: key signature; accidentals not needed]] In principle, any piece can be written with any key signature, using accidentals to correct the pattern of whole and half steps. The purpose of the key signature is to minimize the number of such accidentals required to notate the music. The sequence of sharps or flats in key signatures is generally rigid in modern [[Music notation#Modern notation|music notation]]. This allows musicians to identify the key simply by the number of sharps or flats (which is the same in any clef), rather than their position on the staff. For example, if a key signature has only one sharp, it must be an [[F♯ (musical note)|F-sharp]],|url=http://www.dummies.com/how-to/content/how-to-read-key-signatures.html |title=How to Read Key Signatures|accessdate=29 January 2014 which corresponds to a [[G major]] or an [[E minor]] key. However, in 20th-century music, there are occasional exceptions to this, where a piece uses an unorthodox or synthetic scale, where a key signature may be invented to reflect this. This may consist of a number of sharps or flats that are not the normal ones (such as a signature of just C{{music|sharp}} or E{{music|flat}}), or it may consist of one or more sharps combined with one or more flats (such as a signature containing both F{{music|sharp}} and B{{music|flat}}). Key signatures of this kind can be found in the music of [[Béla Bartók]], for example. The effect of a key signature continues throughout a piece or movement, unless explicitly cancelled by another key signature. For example, if a five-sharp key signature is placed at the beginning of a piece, every A in the piece in any [[octave]] will be played as A sharp, unless preceded by an accidental (for instance, the A in [[#scale2|scale 2]] illustrated – the next-to-last note – is played as an A{{music|sharp}} even though the A{{music|sharp}} in the key signature (the last sharp sign) is written an octave lower). In a score containing more than one instrument, all the instruments are usually written with the same key signature. Exceptions include: * If an instrument is a [[transposing instrument]]. * If an instrument is a [[percussion instrument]] with indeterminate pitch. * Composers usually omit the key signature for [[timpani]] parts. Besides not using a key signature, timpani parts were early on also treated often as transposing instrument parts, the pitch of the high drum being written as C and, as timpani were almost always tuned a [[perfect fourth]] apart (dominant on the low drum and tonic on the high drum), the pitch of the low drum being written as G, with the actual pitches indicated at the beginning of the part, e.g. "timpani in D–A", if they were tuned A (low drum) and D (high drum). * Composers may omit the key signature for [[French horn|horn]] and occasionally [[trumpet]] parts. This is perhaps reminiscent of the early days of brass instruments, when [[Crook (music)|crooks]] would be added to them, in order to change the length of the tubing and allow playing in different keys.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} * On occasion, in more modern works, instruments may be notated in different keys even when they are not transposing instruments, because the music is [[polytonal]] and the different parts are actually in different keys which sound together. [[File:Circle of fifths deluxe 4.svg|thumb|right|400px|[[Circle of fifths]] showing [[major key|major]] and [[minor key]]s and their signatures]] === Notational conventions === The convention for the notation of key signatures follows the [[circle of fifths]]. Starting from [[C major]] (or equivalently [[A minor]]) which has no sharps or flats, successively raising the key by a fifth adds a sharp, going clockwise round the circle of fifths. The new sharp is placed on the new key's [[leading note]] (seventh degree) for major keys or [[supertonic]] (second degree) for minor keys. Thus [[G major]] ([[E minor]]) has one sharp which is on the F; then [[D major]] ([[B minor]]) has two sharps on F and C and so on. Similarly, successively lowering the key by a fifth adds a flat, going counterclockwise around the circle of fifths. The new flat is placed on the [[subdominant]] (fourth degree) for major keys or [[submediant]] (sixth degree) for minor keys. Thus [[F major]] ([[D minor]]) has one flat which is on the B; then [[B-flat major|B{{music|flat}} major]] ([[G minor]]) has two flats (on B and E) and so on. Put another way: for key signatures with sharps, the first sharp is placed on F with subsequent sharps on C, G, D, A, E and B; for key signatures with flats, the first flat is placed on B with subsequent flats on E, A, D, G, C and F. There are thus 15 conventional key signatures, with up to seven sharps or flats and including the ''empty'' signature of C major (A minor). Corollaries: * Starting from a key with flats in its key signature: raising by fifths successively reduces the flats to zero at C major (A minor). Further such raising adds sharps as described above. * Starting from a key with sharps: lowering by fifths successively reduces those sharps to zero. Further such lowering adds flats as described above. * When the process of raising by a fifth (adding a sharp) produces more than five or six sharps, successive such raising generally involves changing to the [[enharmonic equivalent]] key using a flat-based signature. Typically this is at F{{music|sharp}} = G{{music|flat}}, but may also be at C{{music|sharp}} = D{{music|flat}} or B = C{{music|flat}}. The same principle applies to the process of successive lowering by a fifth. The relative minor is a [[minor third]] down from the major, regardless of whether it is a ''flat'' or a ''sharp'' key signature. The key signatures with seven flats ({{Music|flat}}) and seven sharps ({{Music|sharp}}) are rarely used because they have simpler enharmonic equivalents. For example, the key of [[C-sharp major|C{{music|#}} major]] (seven sharps) is more simply represented as [[D-flat major|D{{music|b}} major]] (five flats). For modern practical purposes these keys are (in twelve tone [[equal temperament]]) the same, because C{{music|#}} and D{{music|b}} are enharmonically the same note. Pieces ''are'' written in these ''extreme'' sharp or flat keys, however: for example, [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]]'s Prelude and Fugue No. 3 from Book 1 of [[The Well-Tempered Clavier]] [[List of compositions of Johann Sebastian Bach#The Well-Tempered Clavier .28846.E2.80.93893.29|BWV 848]] is in C{{music|#}} major. The modern musical ''[[Seussical]]'' by [[Stephen Flaherty|Flaherty]] and [[Lynn Ahrens|Ahrens]] also has several songs written in these extreme keys. Key signatures can be further extended through [[double sharp]]s and [[double flat]]s (for example, a piece in the key of G{{music|#}} major can be expressed with a double sharp on F{{music|x}} and six sharps on the other six pitches). As with the seven-sharp and seven-flat examples, it is rarely necessary to express music in such keys when simpler enharmonic examples can instead be used (in the case of G{{music|#}}, the same passage could be expressed in A{{music|b}} with only four flats). [[File:Natural key signature example.png|thumb|Natural key signature: a key signature with seven [[Natural (music)|naturals]] ({{Music|natural}}) used to cancel the seven sharps ({{Music|sharp}}) of the previous signature.]] The key signature may be changed at any time in a piece, usually at the beginning of a [[measure (music)|measure]], simply by notating the new signature, although if the new signature has no sharps or flats, a signature of naturals, as shown, is needed to cancel the preceding signature. If a change in signature occurs at the start of a new line on the page, where a signature would normally appear anyway, the new signature is customarily repeated at the end of the previous line to make the change more conspicuous. === Variants of standard conventions === In traditional use, when the key signature change goes from sharps to flats or vice versa, the old key signature is cancelled with the appropriate number of naturals before the new one is inserted; but many more recent publications (whether of newer music or newer editions of older music) dispense with the naturals and simply insert the new signature. Similarly, when a signature with either flats or sharps in it changes to a smaller signature of the same type, strict application of tradition or convention would require that naturals first be used to cancel just those flats or sharps that are being subtracted in the new signature before the new signature itself is written; but, again, more modern usage often dispenses with these naturals. When the signature changes from a smaller to a larger signature of the same type, the new signature is simply written in by itself, in both traditional and newer styles. At one time it was usual to precede the new signature with a [[barline|double barline]] (provided the change occurred between bars and not inside a bar), even if it was not required by the structure of the music to mark sections within the movement; but more recently it has increasingly become usual to use just a single barline. The courtesy signature that appears at the end of a line immediately before a change is usually preceded by an additional barline; the line at the very end of the staff is omitted in this case. If both naturals and a new key signature appear at a key signature change, there are also more recently variations about where a barline will be placed (in the case where the change occurs between bars). For example, in some scores by Debussy, in this situation the barline is placed after the naturals but before the new key signature. Hitherto, it would have been more usual to place all the symbols after the barline. In key signatures of five or more sharps or of seven flats, one occasionally encounters variant positions of particular symbols in the key signatures, both of them in the bass clef. The A{{music|sharp}} which is the fifth sharp in the sharp signatures may occasionally be notated on the top line of the bass staff, whereas it is more usually found in the lowest space on that staff. An example of this can be seen in the full score of [[Ottorino Respighi]]'s ''[[Pines of Rome]]'', in the third section, "Pines of the Janiculum" (which is in [[B major]]), in the bass-clef instrumental parts. In the case of seven-flat key signatures, the final F{{music|flat}} may occasionally be seen on the second-top line of the bass staff, whereas it would more usually appear below the bottom line. An example of this can be seen in [[Isaac Albéniz]]'s ''[[Iberia (Albéniz)|Iberia]]'': first movement, "Evocación", which is in [[A-flat minor|A{{music|flat}}]] minor. ==Major scale structure== Except for C major, key signatures appear in two varieties, "sharp key signatures" ("sharp keys") and "flat key signatures" ("flat keys"), so called because they contain only one or other.Schonbrun, Marc (2005). ''The Everything Music Theory Book'', p.68. {{ISBN|1-59337-652-9}}. ===Scales with sharp key signatures=== Sharp key signatures consist of a number of sharps between one and seven, applied in this order: {{nowrap|F C G D A E B}}.Bower, Michael. 2007. "[http://www.empire.k12.ca.us/capistrano/Mike/capmusic/Key%20Signatures/key_signatures.htm All about Key Signatures]". Modesto, CA: Capistrano School (K–12) website. (Accessed 17 March 2010).Jones, George Thaddeus. 1974. ''Music Theory: The Fundamental Concepts of Tonal Music Including Notation, Terminology, and Harmony'', p.35. Barnes & Noble Outline Series 137. [[New York City|New York]], Hagerstown, San Francisco, London: [[Barnes & Noble]]. {{ISBN|9780064601375}}. A mnemonic device often used to remember this is "Father Charles Goes Down And Ends Battle."{{Failed verification|date=August 2017}}Schonbrun indeed offers this mnemonic, but makes no claim whatever about frequency of use, or indeed whether it had ever been used before Schonbrun concocted it for his book.--> The key note or [[Tonic (music)|tonic]] of a piece in a major key is immediately above the last sharp in the signature.Kennedy, Michael. 1994. "Key-Signature". ''Oxford Dictionary of Music'', second edition, associate editor, Joyce Bourne. Oxford and New York: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-869162-9}}. For example, one sharp (F{{music|sharp}}) in the key signature of a piece in a major key indicates the key of G major, the next note above F{{music|sharp}}. (Six sharps, the last one being E{{music|sharp}} (an [[enharmonic]] spelling of F{{music|natural}}) indicate the key of F{{music|sharp}} major, since F has already been sharped in the key signature.) {| class="wikitable" |- ! Major key !! Number
of sharps !! Sharp notes !! Minor key !! Enharmonic
equivalent |- | [[C major]] || 0 ||   || [[A minor]] || None |- | [[G major]] || 1 || F{{music|sharp}} || [[E minor]] || None |- | [[D major]] || 2 || F{{music|sharp}}, C{{music|sharp}} || [[B minor]] || None |- | [[A major]] || 3 || F{{music|sharp}}, C{{music|sharp}}, G{{music|sharp}} || [[F-sharp minor|F{{music|sharp}} minor]] || None |- | [[E major]] || 4 || F{{music|sharp}}, C{{music|sharp}}, G{{music|sharp}}, D{{music|sharp}} || [[C-sharp minor|C{{music|sharp}} minor]] || None |- | [[B major]] || 5|| F{{music|sharp}}, C{{music|sharp}}, G{{music|sharp}}, D{{music|sharp}}, A{{music|sharp}} || [[G-sharp minor|G{{music|sharp}} minor]] || [[C-flat major|C{{music|flat}} major]]/[[A-flat minor|A{{music|flat}} minor]] |- | [[F-sharp major|F{{music|sharp}} major]] || 6 || F{{music|sharp}}, C{{music|sharp}}, G{{music|sharp}}, D{{music|sharp}}, A{{music|sharp}}, E{{music|sharp}} || [[D-sharp minor|D{{music|sharp}} minor]] || [[G-flat major|G{{music|flat}} major]]/[[E-flat minor|E{{music|flat}} minor]] |- | [[C-sharp major|C{{music|sharp}} major]] || 7 || F{{music|sharp}}, C{{music|sharp}}, G{{music|sharp}}, D{{music|sharp}}, A{{music|sharp}}, E{{music|sharp}}, B{{music|sharp}} || [[A-sharp minor|A{{music|sharp}} minor]] || [[D-flat major|D{{music|flat}} major]]/[[B-flat minor|B{{music|flat}} minor]] |} This table shows that each scale starting on the [[Perfect fifth|fifth]] [[scale degree]] of the previous scale has one new sharp, added in the order given above. ===Scales with flat key signatures=== "Flat key signatures" consist of one to seven flats, applied as: {{nowrap|B E A D G C F}} The mnemonic device is then reversed for use in the flat keys: "Battle Ends And Down Goes Charles' Father". The major scale with one flat is F major. In all other "flat major scales", the tonic or key note of a piece in a major key is four notes below the last flat, which is the same as the second-to-last flat in the signature. In the major key with four flats (B{{music|flat}} E{{music|flat}} A{{music|flat}} D{{music|flat}}), for example, the penultimate flat is A{{music|flat}}, indicating a key of A{{music|flat}} major. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Major key !! Number
of flats !! Flat notes !! Minor key !! Enharmonic
equivalent |- | [[C major]] || 0 ||   || [[A minor]] || None |- | [[F major]] || 1 || B{{music|flat}} || [[D minor]] || None |- | [[B-flat major|B{{music|flat}} major]] || 2 || B{{music|flat}}, E{{music|flat}} || [[G minor]] || None |- | [[E-flat major|E{{music|flat}} major]] || 3 || B{{music|flat}}, E{{music|flat}}, A{{music|flat}} || [[C minor]] || None |- | [[A-flat major|A{{music|flat}} major]] || 4 || B{{music|flat}}, E{{music|flat}}, A{{music|flat}}, D{{music|flat}} || [[F minor]] || None |- | [[D-flat major|D{{music|flat}} major]] || 5 || B{{music|flat}}, E{{music|flat}}, A{{music|flat}}, D{{music|flat}}, G{{music|flat}} || [[B-flat minor|B{{music|flat}} minor]] || [[C-sharp major|C{{music|sharp}} major]]/[[A-sharp minor|A{{music|sharp}} minor]] |- | [[G-flat major|G{{music|flat}} major]] || 6 || B{{music|flat}}, E{{music|flat}}, A{{music|flat}}, D{{music|flat}}, G{{music|flat}}, C{{music|flat}} || [[E-flat minor|E{{music|flat}} minor]] || [[F-sharp major|F{{music|sharp}} major]]/[[D-sharp minor|D{{music|sharp}} minor]] |- | [[C-flat major|C{{music|flat}} major]] || 7 || B{{music|flat}}, E{{music|flat}}, A{{music|flat}}, D{{music|flat}}, G{{music|flat}}, C{{music|flat}}, F{{music|flat}} || [[A-flat minor|A{{music|flat}} minor]] || [[B major]]/[[G-sharp minor|G{{music|sharp}} minor]] |} In this case each new scale starts a fifth ''below'' (or a [[Perfect fourth|fourth]] above) the previous one. == Relationship between ''key signature'' and ''key'' == A key signature is not the same as a [[key (music)|key]]; key signatures are merely notational devices. They are convenient principally for [[diatonic]] or [[tonality|tonal]] music. The key signature defines the [[diatonic scale]] that a piece of music uses without the need for accidentals. Most [[scale (music)|scales]] require that some notes be consistently sharped or flatted. For example, the only sharp in the G [[major scale]] is F sharp, so the key signature associated with the G major key is the one-sharp key signature. However, it is only a notational convenience; a piece with a one-sharp key signature is not necessarily in the key of G major, and likewise, a piece in G major may not always be written with a one-sharp key signature; this is particularly true in pre-Baroque music, when the concept of key had not yet evolved to its present state. In any case, more extensive pieces often change key (''[[modulation (music)|modulate]]'') during contrasting sections, and only sometimes is this change indicated with a change of key signature; if not, the passage in the second key will not have a matching key signature. [[File:GottesZeit.png|400px|thumb|right|[[Gottes Zeit ist die allerbeste Zeit, BWV 106|Bach Cantata 106]] is almost entirely in E{{music|flat}} major, but has only two flats, not three, in the key signature {{audio|GottesZeit.mid|Play}}]] The [[Toccata and Fugue in D minor, BWV 538]] by [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]] has no key signature, leading it to be called the ''[[Dorian mode|Dorian]]'', but it is still in D minor; the B{{music|flat}}s that occur in the piece are written with accidentals. ===Additional terminology=== Keys which are associated with the same key signature are called [[relative minor/major|relative keys]]. When [[musical mode]]s, such as [[Lydian mode|Lydian]] or Dorian, are written using key signatures, they are called ''transposed modes''. == Exceptions == [[File:D Freygish Noteworthy Composer.png|thumb|D [[Phrygian dominant scale|Freygish]] scale {{audio|D Freygish.mid|Play}}]] Exceptions to [[Common practice period|common-practice-period]] use may be found in [[Klezmer]] scales, such as [[Phrygian dominant scale|Freygish (Phrygian)]]. In the 20th century, composers such as [[Béla Bartók|Bartók]] and [[Frederic Rzewski|Rzewski]] (see below) began experimenting with unusual key signatures that departed from the [[musical mode|standard order]]. Because of the limitations of the traditional [[Great Highland Bagpipe|highland bagpipe]] scale, key signatures are often omitted from written pipe music, which otherwise would be written with two sharps, the usual F{{music|#}} and C{{music|#}}. {{cite web | url = http://lilypond.org/doc/v2.12/Documentation/user/lilypond/Bagpipes#Bagpipes | title = GNU LilyPond — Notation Reference | last1 = Nienhuys | first1 = Han-Wen | last2 = Nieuwenhuizen | first2 = Jan | authorlink1 = Han-Wen Nienhuys | authorlink2 = Jan Nieuwenhuizen | year = 2009 | at = 2.6.2 Bagpipes | accessdate = 2010-03-28 | quote = Bagpipe music nominally uses the key of D Major (even though that isn’t really true). However, since that is the only key that can be used, the key signature is normally not written out. }} (In this case the pipes are incapable of playing F{{music|natural}} and C{{music|natural}} so it is not necessary to specify the sharps.) [[File:Earlykeysig.png|thumb|right|80px|Variant key signatures in a [[Tomas Luis de Victoria|Victoria]] motet. In the ''superius'' (soprano) part the E{{music|flat}} appears first, and in two other parts a flat occurs in two octaves.]] === Unusual signatures === {{further information|Anhemitonic scale#Modes of the ancohemitonic heptatonic scales and the key signature system}} The above 15 key signatures only express diatonic scale. and are therefore sometimes called ''standard key signatures''. Other scales are written either with a standard key signature and use accidental as required, or with a nonstandard key signature. Examples of the latter include the E{{music|b}} (right hand), and F{{music|b}} and G{{music|b}} (left hand) used for the E{{music|b}} diminished (E{{music|b}} [[octatonic scale|octatonic]]) scale in Bartók's ''Crossed Hands'' (no. 99, vol. 4, ''[[Mikrokosmos (Béla Bartók)|Mikrokosmos]]''), or the B{{music|b}}, E{{music|b}} and F{{music|#}} used for the D [[Phrygian dominant scale]] in [[Frederic Rzewski]]'s ''God to a Hungry Child''. The absence of a key signature does not always mean that the music is in the key of C major / A minor as each accidental may be notated explicitly as required, or the piece may be [[Musical mode|modal]] or [[atonality|atonal]]. An example is Bartók's [[Piano Sonata (Bartók)|Piano Sonata]], which has no fixed key and is highly chromatic. If not bound by common practice conventions, [[microtonal music|microtones]] can also be notated in a key signature; which [[List of musical symbols#Quarter tones|microtonal symbols]] are used depends on the system. The [[common practice period]] conventions are so firmly established that some [[scorewriter|musical notation programs]] have been unable to show nonstandard key signatures until recently.One of the most popular musical notation programs, Finale, has only included the option to create a nonstandard key signature since their 2009 version: Finale 2009 User Manual for Windows. "Non-Standard Key Signature." http://www.finalemusic.com/UserManuals/Finale2009Win/Finale.htm (accessed February 17, 2011). == History == The use of a one-flat signature developed in the [[Medieval music|Medieval]] period, but signatures with more than one flat did not appear until the 16th century, and signatures with sharps not until the mid-17th century."Key Signature", ''Harvard Dictionary of Music'', 2nd ed. When signatures with multiple flats first came in, the order of the flats was not standardized, and often a flat appeared in two different octaves, as shown at right. In the late 15th and early 16th centuries, it was common for different voice parts in the same composition to have different signatures, a situation called a '''partial signature''' or '''conflicting signature'''. This was actually more common than complete signatures in the 15th century."Partial Signature", ''Harvard Dictionary of Music'', 2nd ed. The 16th-century motet ''Absolon fili mi'' attributed to [[Josquin des Prez]] features two voice parts with two flats, one part with three flats, and one part with four flats. Baroque music written in [[minor key]]s often was written with a key signature with fewer flats than we now associate with their keys; for example, movements in C minor often had only two flats (because the A{{music|flat}} would frequently have to be sharpened to A{{music|natural}} in the [[minor scale|ascending melodic minor scale]], as would the B{{music|flat}}). == Table == {| | {| class="wikitable" style="background:white; text-align:center; margin:0.5em auto" |- !Key signature !Major key !Minor key |- | align=center|[[File:Treble clef with empty staff.svg|100px|C Major key signature]]
no sharps or flats | [[C major]] | [[A minor]] |} {| class="wikitable" style="background:white; text-align:center; margin:0.5em auto" |- !Key signature !Added {{music|sharp}} !Major key !Minor key !Key signature !Added {{music|flat}} !Major key !Minor key |- | align=center|[[File:G-major e-minor.svg|100px|G Major key signature]]
1 sharp | F{{music|sharp}} | [[G major]] | [[E minor]] | align=center|[[File:F-major d-minor.svg|100px|F Major key signature]]
1 flat | B{{music|flat}} | [[F major]] | [[D minor]] |- | align=center|[[File:D-major h-minor.svg|100px|D Major key signature]]
2 sharps | C{{music|sharp}} | [[D major]] | [[B minor]] | align=center|[[File:B-flat-major g-minor.svg|100px|B-flat Major key signature]]
2 flats | E{{music|flat}} | [[B-flat major|B{{music|flat}} major]] | [[G minor]] |- | align=center|[[File:A-major f-sharp-minor.svg|100px|A Major key signature]]
3 sharps | G{{music|sharp}} | [[A major]] | [[F-sharp minor|F{{music|sharp}} minor]] | align=center|[[File:E-flat-major c-minor.svg|100px|E-flat Major key signature]]
3 flats | A{{music|flat}} | [[E-flat major|E{{music|flat}} major]] | [[C minor]] |- | align=center|[[File:E-major c-sharp-minor.svg|100px|E Major key signature]]
4 sharps | D{{music|sharp}} | [[E major]] | [[C-sharp minor|C{{music|sharp}} minor]] | align=center|[[File:A-flat-major f-minor.svg|100px|A-flat Major key signature]]
4 flats | D{{music|flat}} | [[A-flat major|A{{music|flat}} major]] | [[F minor]] |- | align=center|[[File:B-major g-sharp-minor.svg|100px|B Major key signature]]
5 sharps | A{{music|sharp}} | [[B major]] | [[G-sharp minor|G{{music|sharp}} minor]] | align=center|[[File:D-flat-major b-flat-minor.svg|100px|D-flat Major key signature]]
5 flats | G{{music|flat}} | [[D-flat major|D{{music|flat}} major]] | [[B-flat minor|B{{music|flat}} minor]] |- | align=center|[[File:F-sharp-major d-sharp-minor.svg|100px|F-sharp Major key signature]]
6 sharps | E{{music|sharp}} | [[F-sharp major|F{{music|sharp}} major]] | [[D-sharp minor|D{{music|sharp}} minor]] | align=center|[[File:G-flat-major e-flat-minor.svg|100px|G-flat Major key signature]]
6 flats | C{{music|flat}} | [[G-flat major|G{{music|flat}} major]] | [[E-flat minor|E{{music|flat}} minor]] |- | align=center|[[File:C-sharp-major a-sharp-minor.svg|100px|C-sharp Major key signature]]
7 sharps | B{{music|sharp}} | [[C-sharp major|C{{music|sharp}} major]] | [[A-sharp minor|A{{music|sharp}} minor]] | align=center|[[File:C-flat-major a-flat-minor.svg|100px|C-flat Major key signature]]
7 flats | F{{music|flat}} | [[C-flat major|C{{music|flat}} major]] | [[A-flat minor|A{{music|flat}} minor]] |} |} == See also == * [[Key signature names and translations]] * [[Major and minor]] * [[Parallel key]] * [[Relative key]] * [[Theoretical key]] * [[Universal key]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Musical key}} {{Musical notation}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Key Signature}} [[Category:Musical notation]] [[fi:Sävellaji#Etumerkintä]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edit by [[Special:Contributions/Shekwolo PD|Shekwolo PD]] using [[WP:STiki|STiki]]
revision.text:
'''Landfarming''' is an [[Biotreatment#Ex-situ Bioremediation of Contaminated Soils|ex-situ waste treatment process]] that is performed in the upper [[soil]] zone or in biotreatment cells. [[Soil contamination|Contaminated soils]], [[sediment]]s, or [[sludge]]s are transported to the landfarming site, incorporated into the [[topsoil|soil surface]] and periodically turned over ([[tillage|tilled]]) to [[aerate]] the mixture.<ref>{{citation|title=Best Practice Note: Landfarming|year=April 2014|publisher=Environment Protection Authority|location=Sydney NSW|ISBN=978-1-74359-607-4|url=http://www.epa.nsw.gov.au/resources/clm/140323landfarmbpn.pdf}}</ref> Landfarming commonly uses a [[clay]] or [[composite liner]] to intercept [[leachate|leaching]] contaminants and prevent [[groundwater pollution]],<ref>{{citation|chapter=4.13 Landfarming|title=Remediation Technologies Screening Matrix and Reference Guide|version=4th Edition|date=January 2002|author1=Julie Van Deuren |author2=Teressa Lloyd |author3=Shobha Chhetry |author4=Raycharn Liou |author5=James Peck |publisher=Federal Remediation Technology Roundtable (FRTR)|location=U.S. Army Environmental Center, MD|url=https://frtr.gov/matrix2/section4/4_13a.html}}</ref> however, a liner is not a universal requirement.<ref>{{citation|page=114|title=Encyclopedia of Agricultural, Food, and Biological Engineering|editor=Dennis R. Heldman|publisher=CRC Press|year=2003|isbn=978-0824709389|quote="Landfarming is mostly conducted in lined or unlined soil beds that..." }}</ref>
==Applicability== This technique has been used for years in the management and disposal of [[drill cuttings]], oily sludge and other [[gasoline|petroleum]] refinery wastes. The equipment employed in land farming is typical of that used in [[agriculture|agricultural]] operations. These land farming activities cultivate and enhance [[Microorganism|microbial]] degradation of hazardous compounds. As a rule of thumb, the higher the [[molecular weight]] (i.e., the more rings within a [[polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon]]), the slower the degradation rate. Also, the more [[chlorine|chlorinated]] or [[nitration|nitrated]] the compound, the more difficult it is to degrade.<ref>{{cite book|last=Theodore|first=L|title=Introduction to Hazardous Waste Incineration|year=1987|publisher=Wiley|location=New York|author2=Reynolds, J }}</ref>
==Limitations== Factors that may limit the applicability and effectiveness of the process include:
#large space requirements #the conditions advantageous for biological degradation of contaminants are largely uncontrolled, which increases the required length of time until complete degradation, particularly for recalcitrant compounds #inorganic contaminants are not biodegraded #the potential of large amounts of [[particulates|particulate matter]] released by operations #the presence of metal ions may be toxic to microbes and may leach from the contaminated soil into the ground.
Hydrocarbon compounds that have been identified as being not readily degraded by land farming include [[creosote]], [[pentachlorophenol]] (PCP), and [[fuel oil#Bunker fuel|bunker C oil]].
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Environmental soil science]]

{{short description|List of eukaryotic species which have one of their cell dimensions smaller than 3 µm}} List of [[Eukaryote|eukaryotic]] species that belong to [[picoplankton]], meaning one of their cell dimensions is smaller than 3 [[Micrometre|µm]].
==[[Photosynthetic picoplankton|Autotrophic species]]== ===[[Chlorophyta]]=== ====[[Chlorophyceae]]====
* ''[[Stichococcus cylindricus]]'' <small>Butcher</small>, 3 - 4.5 µm, brackish
====[[Pedinophyceae]]==== * ''[[Marsupiomonas pelliculata]]'' <small>Jones ''et al.''</small>, 3 - 3 µm, brackish-marine * ''[[Resultor micron]]'' <small>Moestrup</small>, 1.5 - 2.5 µm, marine
====[[Prasinophyceae]]==== * ''[[Bathycoccus prasinos]]'' <small>Eikrem et Throndsen</small>, 1.5 - 2.5 µm, marine * ''[[Crustomastix stigmatica]]'' <small>Zingone</small>, 3 - 5 µm, marine * ''[[Dolichomastix lepidota]]'' <small>Manton</small>, 2.5 - 2.5 µm, marine * ''[[Dolichomastix eurylepidea]]'' <small>Manton</small>, 3 µm, marine * ''[[Dolichomastix tenuilepis]]'' <small>Throndsen et Zingone</small>, 3 - 4.5 µm, marine * ''[[Mantoniella squamata]]'' <small>Desikachary</small>, 3 - 5 µm, marine * ''[[Micromonas pusilla]]'' <small>Manton et Parke</small>, 1 - 3 µm, marine * ''[[Ostreococcus tauri]]'' <small>Courties et Chrétiennot-Dinet</small>, 0.8 - 1.1 µm, marine * ''[[Picocystis salinarum]]'' <small>Lewin</small>, 2 - 3 µm, hypersaline * ''[[Prasinococcus capsulatus]]'' <small>Miyashita et Chihara</small>, 3 - 5.5 µm, marine * ''[[Prasinoderma coloniale]]'' <small>Hasegawa et Chihara</small>, 2.5 - 5.5 µm, marine * ''[[Pseudoscourfieldia marina]]'' <small>Manton</small>, 3 - 3.5 µm, marine * ''[[Pycnococcus provasolii]]'' <small>Guillard</small>, 1.5 - 4 µm, marine * ''[[Pyramimonas virginica]]'' <small>Pennick</small>, 2.7 - 3.5 µm, marine
====[[Trebouxiophyceae]]==== * ''[[Chlorella nana]]'' <small>Andreoli ''et al.''</small>, 1.5 - 3 µm, marine * ''[[Picochlorum oklahomensis]]'' <small>Henley ''et al.''</small>, 2 - 2 µm, hypersaline * ''[[Picochlorum atomus]]'' <small>Henley ''et al.''</small>, 2 - 3 µm, brackish * ''[[Picochlorum eukaryotum]]'' <small>Henley ''et al.''</small>, 3 - 3 µm, marine * ''[[Picochlorum maculatus]]'' <small>Henley ''et al.''</small>, 3 - 3 µm, brackish
===[[Cryptophyta]]=== ====[[Cryptophyceae]]==== * ''[[Hillea marina]]'' <small>Butcher</small>, 1.5 - 2.5 µm, marine
===[[Haptophyta]]=== ====[[Prymnesiaceae]]==== * ''[[Chrysochromulina tenuisquama]]'' <small>Estep ''et al.''</small>, 2 - 5 µm, marine * ''[[Chrysochromulina minor]]'' <small>Parke et Manton</small>, 2.5 - 7.5 µm, marine * ''[[Chrysochromulina apheles]]'' <small>Moestrup et Thomsen</small>, 3 - 4 µm, marine * ''[[Dicrateria inornata]]'' <small>Parke</small>, 3 - 5.5 µm, marine * ''[[Ericiolus spiculiger]]'' <small>Thomsen</small>, 3 - 3.8 µm, marine * ''[[Imantonia rotunda]]'' <small>Reynolds</small>, 2 - 4 µm, marine * ''[[Phaeocystis cordata]]'' <small>Zingone</small>, 3 - 4 µm, marine * ''[[Phaeocystis pouchetii]]'' <small>Lagerheim</small>, 3 - 8 µm, marine * ''[[Trigonaspis minutissima]]'' <small>H.A.Thomsen</small>, 2 - 3.6 µm, marine
===[[Heterokontophyta]] ([[Stramenopiles]]) === ====[[Bacillariophyceae]]==== * ''[[Minidiscus comicus]]'' <small>Takano</small>, 2 - 7 µm, marine * ''[[Minidiscus trioculatus]]'' <small>Hasle</small>, 2.5 - 3.8 µm, marine * ''[[Minidiscus spinulosus]]'' <small>Gao, Chang et Chin</small>, 3 - 5 µm, marine * ''[[Minidiscus chilensis]]'' <small>Rivera</small>, 3 - 7.5 µm, marine * ''[[Minutocellus polymorphus]]'' <small>Hasle, von Stosch et Syverstsen</small>, 2 - 30 µm, marine * ''[[Minutocellus scriptus]]'' <small>Hasle, von Stosch et Syverstsen</small>, 3 - 36 µm, marine * ''[[Skeletonema menzelii]]'' <small>Guillard, Carpenter et Reimann</small>, 2 - 7 µm, marine * ''[[Skeletonema pseudocostatum]]'' <small>Medlin</small>, 2 - 9 µm, marine * ''[[Skeletonema japonicum]]'' <small>Zingone et Sarno</small>, 2 - 10 µm, marine * ''[[Skeletonema grethae]]'' <small>Zingone et Sarno</small>, 2 - 10.5 µm, marine * ''[[Skeletonema marinoi]]'' <small>Sarno et Zingone</small>, 2 - 12 µm, marine * ''[[Thalassiosira pseudonana]]'' <small>Hasle et Heimdal</small>, 2.3 - 5.5 µm, marine
====[[Bolidophyceae]]==== * ''[[Bolidomonas pacifica]]'' <small>Guillou et Chrétiennot-Dinet</small>, 1 - 1.7 µm, marine * ''[[Bolidomonas mediterranea]]'' <small>Guillou et Chrétiennot-Dinet</small>, 1 - 1.7 µm, marine
====[[Chrysophyceae]]==== * ''[[Ollicola vangoorii]]'' <small>Conrad (Vors)</small>, 2.5 - 5 µm, marine * ''[[Tetraparma pelagica]]'' <small>Booth et Marchant</small>, 2.2 - 2.8 µm, marine * ''[[Tetraparma insecta]]'' <small>Bravo-Sierra et Hernández-Becerril</small>, 2.8 - 3.8 µm, marine * ''[[Triparma laevis]]'' <small>Booth</small>, 2.2 - 3.1 µm, marine * ''[[Triparma columacea]]'' <small>Booth</small>, 2.3 - 4.7 µm, marine * ''[[Triparma retinervis]]'' <small>Booth</small>, 2.7 - 4.5 µm, marine
====[[Dictyochophyceae]]==== * ''[[Florenciella parvula]]'' <small>Eikrem</small>, 3 - 6 µm, marine
====[[Eustigmatophyte|Eustigmatophyceae]]==== * ''[[Nannochloropsis granulata]]'' <small>Karlson et Potter</small>, 2 - 4 µm, marine * ''[[Nannochloropsis salina]]'' <small>Hibberd</small>, 3 - 4 µm, brackish * ''[[Nannochloropsis oceanica]]'' <small>Suda et Miyashita</small>, 3 - 5 µm, marine
====[[Pelagophyceae]]==== * ''[[Aureococcus anophagefferens]]'' <small>Hargraves et Sieburth</small>, 1.5 - 2 µm, marine * ''[[Aureoumbra lagunensis]]'' <small>Stockwell ''et al.''</small>, 2.5 - 5 µm, marine * ''[[Pelagococcus subviridis]]'' <small>Norris</small>, 2.5 - 5.5 µm, marine * ''[[Pelagomonas calceolata]]'' <small>Andersen et Saunders</small>, 2 - 3 µm, marine
====[[Pinguiophyceae]]==== * ''[[Pinguiochrysis pyriformis]]'' <small>Kawachi</small>, 1 - 3 µm, marine * ''[[Pinguiococcus pyrenoidosus]]'' <small>Andersen ''et al.''</small>, 3 - 8 µm, marin
==[[Heterotrophic picoplankton|Heterotrophic species]]== ===[[Cercozoa]]=== ====[[Cercomonadida]]==== * ''[[Massisteria marina]]'' <small>Larsen et Patterson</small>, 2.5 - 6.5 µm, marine
====[[Plasmodiophorida]]==== * ''[[Phagomyxa odontellae]]'' <small>Kühn, Schnepf & Bulman</small>, 3 - 4 µm, marine
===[[Stramenopiles]]=== ====[[Bicosoecida]]==== * ''[[Caecitellus parvulus]]'' <small>Patterson ''et al.''</small>, 3 - 10 µm, marine * ''[[Pseudobodo minima]]'' <small>Ruinen</small>, 2 µm, marine * ''[[Symbiomonas scintillans]]'' <small>Guillou et Chrétiennot-Dinet</small>, 1.2 - 1.5 µm, marine
====[[Chrysophyceae]]==== * ''[[Paraphysomonas imperforata]]'' <small>Lucas</small>, 1.7 - 5.1 µm, marine * ''[[Paraphysomonas corbidifera]]'' <small>Pennick and Clarke</small>, 2 - 3.25 µm, marine * ''[[Paraphysomonas antarctica]]'' <small>Takahashi</small>, 2 - 4.3 µm, marine * ''[[Paraphysomonas caelifrica]]'' <small>Preisig and Hibberd</small>, 2.5 - 5 µm, marine * ''[[Paraphysomonas cribosa]]'' <small>Lucas</small>, 3 - 4 µm, marine * ''[[Paraphysomonas sideriophora]]'' <small>Thomsen</small>, 3 - 5 µm, marine * ''[[Paraphysomonas capreolata]]'' <small>Preisig and Hibberd</small>, 3 - 6.5 µm, marine * ''[[Paraphysomonas gladiata]]'' <small>Preisig and Hibberd</small>, 3 - 8 µm, marine * ''[[Picophagus flagellatus]]'' <small>Guillou et Chrétiennot-Dinet</small>, 1.4 - 2.5 µm, marine
{{plankton}}
